cluster_relations.rel_desc: Caterpillars feed on leaves as their primary food source.

qualifiers.OperationalConstraint: most of their time is spent feeding
qualifiers.OtherQualifier: Behavior: voracious eating; Effect: rapid growth

cluster_relations.rel_desc: Butterflies are prey for birds, serving as a food source.

qualifiers.CausalHint: serve as a food source for

cluster_relations.rel_desc: Butterflies serve as prey for reptiles.

qualifiers.CausalHint: serve as a food source for

cluster_relations.rel_desc: Butterflies serve as prey for other insects.

qualifiers.CausalHint: serve as a food source for

args.canonical_rel_desc: Indicates that the subject organism consumes the object as a primary food source.
args.justification: This relation instance describes a consumer-resource feeding interaction (caterpillars consuming leaves). The natural, directionally correct predicate is 'feeds_on' from consumer to food item.

args.canonical_rel_desc: Indicates that the subject organism is hunted or consumed as prey by the object organism.
args.justification: All three instances describe butterflies serving as prey (food) for different predator groups (birds, reptiles, other insects) with the same direction: prey (subject) to predator (object). A single canonical predicate 'is_prey_of' consistently captures this.

All relations describe feeding or predator–prey (consumer–resource) interactions, which fall under the same broader class of trophic interactions, regardless of whether the direction is consumer→resource or prey→predator.
Each relation represents a biological interaction between organisms (feeding/predation), fitting the broad category of INTERACTION rather than composition, identity, or causality.
